issues.description: Constructor parameter order for Meal is inconsistent between the problem statement (and example usage in Main) and the template. The UML and the example usage expect Meal(String name, String[] ingredients), but the template's Meal constructor is declared as Meal(String[] ingredients, String name). This will confuse students and cause compilation errors if they follow the provided Main or the UML signature.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Meal constructor signature in the template match the UML and example usage: change the constructor to public Meal(String name, String[] ingredients) and assign fields accordingly. Alternatively, update the example usage and UML to match the template, but keeping the constructor signature as (String name, String[]) is recommended to match the problem statement and solution.

issues.description: The problem statement gives conflicting guidance about the SealSaloon.stock field: one part instructs initializing a final Stock in the SealSaloon constructor (implying an instance field), while a later explicit note requires the stock attribute to be static (shared across instances). This contradiction can confuse students about whether stock should be an instance final field initialized in the constructor or a static shared field.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the problem statement: explicitly state that stock is a static (shared) field and how it should be initialized (e.g., initialize at declaration or in a static initializer). Remove or revise the sentence that says to initialize stock in the instance constructor, since static fields are not per-instance. Align the UML/description to clearly indicate stock is static final.

issues.description: Constructor parameter order for the Meal class is inconsistent across artifacts. The problem statement's class diagram specifies Meal(String, String[]) (i.e., name then ingredients), and the solution implements public Meal(String name, String[] ingredients). The template, however, defines the constructor as public Meal(String[] ingredients, String name) (ingredients then name). This inversion of parameter order will confuse students: example usages in the template Main and problem examples use new Meal("cowBoyStew", new String[]{...}) which does not match the template's Meal constructor and will cause compilation errors or extra cognitive effort to map the requirement to the provided code.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the Meal constructor parameter order consistent with the problem statement and solution: change the template's constructor signature to public Meal(String name, String[] ingredients). Alternatively, update all example usages (Main and problem examples) to match the template's current signature, but aligning the template constructor to (String name, String[] ingredients) is recommended to match the stated requirements and the solution.
